title: The Satanic Verses

cover.description: Cover of 2008 Random House trade paperback edition.
cover.alt: Paperback book cover with author's name and title shows in alternating blue and green letters, and a central purple image of a stylized human figure apparently in mid-tumble, with arms outstretched and a long braid streaming up from the figure's head. Other text on the page includes '#1 NEW YORK TIME BESTSELLER' and a blurb by Nadine Gordimer saying 'A staggering achivement, brilliantly enjoyable.'

overview: A magical realist novel featuring two Indian actors miraculously surviving a terrorist bombing of a flight to London, and dream sequences involving various religious figures (including one based on the prophet Muhammad).  It won the Whitbread award for novel of the year and was a finalist for the Booker Prize.

incidents.description: The Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, supreme leader of Iran (and the basis for a satirical character in one of the book's dream sequences) pronounced a fatwa calling on 'all zealous Muslims' to kill the author and 'all those involved in [the book's] publication'. Rushdie went into hiding for several years following this pronouncement. Several Muslim-majority countries prohibited the book's publication or importation. A series of violent attacks against those involved with the book include the 1991 murder of a Japanese translator, riots in Turkey that killed more than 30 people in 1993, the shooting of the book's Norwegian publisher the same year, and a stabbing attack in the US in 2022 that seriously injured the author.
